fullText: The 2016 revival of 'Falsettos' is a deeply moving experience that reminds us why this musical has endured. The performances are uniformly excellent, and the staging brings fresh insight to this tale of love, family, and loss.
dtliExcerpt: The 2016 revival of 'Falsettos' is a deeply moving experience that reminds us why this musical has endured. The performances are uniformly excellent, and the staging brings fresh insight to this tale of love, family, and loss.
bwwExcerpt: Notwithstanding Mr. Finn's inability to write once-heard-never-forgotten tunes, the musical numbers are cleverly crafted and the overall tone is appropriately tart, this being a show in which no one is very likable. (The title of the first song, 'Four Jews in a Room Bitching,' sums up 'March of the Falsettos' pretty comprehensively.) In 'Falsettoland,' by contrast, a hideously painful situation is portrayed with a sincere but cloying sentimentality that occasionally curdles into kitsch. If you're old enough to have witnessed the AIDS epidemic at first hand, the second act of 'Falsettos' might just make you cry in spite of yourself. If not...well, it probably won't.
showScoreExcerpt: The 2016 revival of 'Falsettos' is a deeply moving experience that reminds us why this musical has endured. The performances are uniformly excellent, and the staging brings fresh insight to this tale of love, family, and loss.
rejectionReasoning: openai: The review is about the 2016 revival of 'Falsettos', not the current Broadway run.; kimi: The text explicitly reviews the '2016 revival' of Falsettos, which is a previous production from 2016 and not the current Broadway run.
